prerequisite.treatment_framework:
{Initial Part of Session:  
Set the agenda: t1(“那 今天 我 我 一定 要 分享 一下...”), t1(“那 今天 很 謝謝 你 來 然後也 再 一次 的 恭喜 你...”),
Mood check: c1(“哇 很 感動”), c1(“我 是 覺得”), c1(“嗯 對 我 就是 對 我蠻 易怒 的...”),
Obtain an update: c1(“我 現 在 是 很 狀況 很 差。”), c1(“我 現 在 需要 在 想 自己 的 書 的 時候...”),
Discuss the patient's diagnosis and provide psychoeducation: t1(“我 覺得 就是 你 很 特別 的 地方...”),
Review homework: None observed,
Prioritize the agenda: t1(“那 今天 我們 就 一起 邀請...”),
Explaination:  
The session begins with the therapist setting the agenda by introducing topics to discuss and framing the conversation (t1 lines about sharing and thanking). Mood check is informally conducted as the patient expresses feelings (c1’s emotional reactions). The therapist obtains an update on the patient’s current state, e.g., reading habits and current work status. There is some psychoeducation or normalization of feelings and experiences, e.g., discussing language use and cultural identity issues. No explicit homework review or agenda prioritization is observed, but some agenda setting occurs implicitly.  
}  

{Middle Part of Session:  
Identify problems and set goals: c1(“我 覺得 我 在 事業 上 很 成功 的 話...” to “感情 可能 不是 像 事業 一樣 能夠 由 你 塑造”), t1(“我 想要 跟 你 聊 一個 也 是 你 在 其他 地方 沒有 聊過 的 一件 事情...”),
Educate the patient about the cognitive model: t1(“我 覺得 就是 你 很 特別 的 地方 是 你 對 臺 灣的 認同...”),
Discuss a problem: c1(“我 會 會 有 被 質疑 的 空間”), c1(“有 一次 有 一個 讀者 沒 有 看 作品 就 來 參加 活動...”),
Work on a specific problem and teach CBT skills within that context: t1(“就算 你 有 一些 回 他 的 話 稍微 沖 一點 我 都 覺得 這是 你 正常 的 反應...”), t1(“如果 今天 你 沒 有 惡意 而 你 卻 表達 出來 讓 別人 有 被 冒犯 到 的 感覺 的 時候 你 自己 也 要 去 注意 一下 你 自己 的 措辭 啊”),
Follow-up discussion with relevant, collaboratively set homework assignments: None explicit but some encouragement to reflect and consider feedback (t1 and c1 discussing reactions to social interactions),
Work on a second problem: c1 and t1 discuss interpersonal relationships and emotional regulation issues later in the session,
Explaination:  
The middle part involves exploring the patient’s problems such as identity issues, interpersonal conflicts, and emotional responses (e.g., irritability, feeling questioned). The therapist provides cognitive restructuring by normalizing emotional reactions and encouraging reflection on communication (a CBT skill). There is psychoeducation about language and identity, consistent with cognitive model education. There is also some discussion around emotional regulation and relationship dynamics, indicating work on a second problem. Explicit homework setting is not observed but the dialogue implies encouragement of self-monitoring and reflection.  
}  

{End of Session:  
Provide or elicit a summary: t1(“那 今天 很 謝謝 你 來 然後也 再 一次 的 恭喜 你...”),
Review new homework assignments: None explicit,
Elicit feedback: c1’s expressions of agreement, t1’s encouragements to share more in future interviews,
Explaination:  
At the session end, the therapist provides a summary and closing remarks, expressing gratitude and summarizing key themes (achievement, identity, contribution). No explicit homework is assigned or reviewed, and feedback is informally elicited through the patient’s participation and openness. The closing emphasizes positive reinforcement and encouragement for future growth.  
}

{Initial Part of Session:  
Set the agenda: t1(“那 今天 我 我 一定 要 分享 一下...”), t1(“那 今天 很 謝謝 你 來 然後也 再 一次 的 恭喜 你...”),
Mood check: c1(“哇 很 感動”), c1(“我 是 覺得”), c1(“嗯 對 我 就是 對 我蠻 易怒 的...”),
Obtain an update: c1(“我 現 在 是 很 狀況 很 差。”), c1(“我 現 在 需要 在 想 自己 的 書 的 時候...”),
Discuss the patient's diagnosis and provide psychoeducation: t1(“我 覺得 就是 你 很 特別 的 地方...”),
Review homework: None observed,
Prioritize the agenda: t1(“那 今天 我們 就 一起 邀請...”),
Explaination:  
The session begins with the therapist setting the agenda by introducing topics to discuss and framing the conversation (t1 lines about sharing and thanking). Mood check is informally conducted as the patient expresses feelings (c1’s emotional reactions). The therapist obtains an update on the patient’s current state, e.g., reading habits and current work status. There is some psychoeducation or normalization of feelings and experiences, e.g., discussing language use and cultural identity issues. No explicit homework review or agenda prioritization is observed, but some agenda setting occurs implicitly.  
}  

{Middle Part of Session:  
Identify problems and set goals: c1(“我 覺得 我 在 事業 上 很 成功 的 話...” to “感情 可能 不是 像 事業 一樣 能夠 由 你 塑造”), t1(“我 想要 跟 你 聊 一個 也 是 你 在 其他 地方 沒有 聊過 的 一件 事情...”),
Educate the patient about the cognitive model: t1(“我 覺得 就是 你 很 特別 的 地方 是 你 對 臺 灣的 認同...”),
Discuss a problem: c1(“我 會 會 有 被 質疑 的 空間”), c1(“有 一次 有 一個 讀者 沒 有 看 作品 就 來 參加 活動...”),
Work on a specific problem and teach CBT skills within that context: t1(“就算 你 有 一些 回 他 的 話 稍微 沖 一點 我 都 覺得 這是 你 正常 的 反應...”), t1(“如果 今天 你 沒 有 惡意 而 你 卻 表達 出來 讓 別人 有 被 冒犯 到 的 感覺 的 時候 你 自己 也 要 去 注意 一下 你 自己 的 措辭 啊”),
Follow-up discussion with relevant, collaboratively set homework assignments: None explicit but some encouragement to reflect and consider feedback (t1 and c1 discussing reactions to social interactions),
Work on a second problem: c1 and t1 discuss interpersonal relationships and emotional regulation issues later in the session,
Explaination:  
The middle part involves exploring the patient’s problems such as identity issues, interpersonal conflicts, and emotional responses (e.g., irritability, feeling questioned). The therapist provides cognitive restructuring by normalizing emotional reactions and encouraging reflection on communication (a CBT skill). There is psychoeducation about language and identity, consistent with cognitive model education. There is also some discussion around emotional regulation and relationship dynamics, indicating work on a second problem. Explicit homework setting is not observed but the dialogue implies encouragement of self-monitoring and reflection.  
}  

{End of Session:  
Provide or elicit a summary: t1(“那 今天 很 謝謝 你 來 然後也 再 一次 的 恭喜 你...”),
Review new homework assignments: None explicit,
Elicit feedback: c1’s expressions of agreement, t1’s encouragements to share more in future interviews,
Explaination:  
At the session end, the therapist provides a summary and closing remarks, expressing gratitude and summarizing key themes (achievement, identity, contribution). No explicit homework is assigned or reviewed, and feedback is informally elicited through the patient’s participation and openness. The closing emphasizes positive reinforcement and encouragement for future growth.  
}
